awd_abstract_narration:
Coacervates are complexes of oppositely charged polymers that have separated into two liquid phases from a salt solution due to electrostatic forces.  They are used in coatings, adhesives, pharmaceuticals, and personal care products.  This research will create novel coacervates in which one of the charged components is a solid nanoparticle.  The work will create new coacervates by building on existing knowledge, explore how particle size and rigidity affect the formation of the two liquid phases, and examine the role that the arrangement of charges on the particle surface plays.  Experiments to map the phase diagrams for these new materials will be complemented by analysis, experiments to identify the adsorption of polymers on the particle surfaces and the polymer configurations, and experiments to measure the bulk mechanical behavior.  Ultimately, the researchers plan to identify design rules for the formulation of coacervates using a broad class of particles.  Research opportunities for women and other students who are under-represented in STEM fields will be provided as part of this work.

This award is focused on a systematic study of polymer-particle coacervates.  Three specific aims for the work are:  1) create polymer-particle coacervates employing particles with polymers attached (brushy particles) to build upon the current understanding of polymer-polymer coacervate systems, 2) examine how particle rigidity and size impact coacervate formation and properties, and 3) examine the role of charge clustering on coacervate formation by focusing on electrostatically patchy particles.  The three aims decouple the hypothesized mechanisms by which particle properties affect coacervate formation, thus providing design rules for the formulation of coacervates using broad classes of particles. By comparing coacervate formation with brushy particles to the analogous system of linear polycation and polyanion chains, Aim 1 preserves the molecular interactions of a classical coacervate and introduces solid particles as space filling entities whose length scales may be important through their range of interactions. Aims 2 and 3 sequentially probe the impact of molecular scale constraints introduced by particle rigidity, potential mismatch in registration of positive and negative charge, and charge clustering.  The program exploits the synergy between the principle investigators: Perry (coacervate expert) and Santore (expert on polyelectrolyte adsorption and colloidal phase behavior). The experiments at UMass will be supported by computations by collaborator Sing at UIUC whose calculations address both the polymer-solid interactions and the phase behavior.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this NSF CBET award was to conduct fundamental research into the preparation of dense, liquid complex coacervates resulting from the interactions between oppositely-charged polymers and nanoparticles. Complex coacervates are complexes of oppositely charged polymers that have separated into two liquid phases from a salt solution due to electrostatic forces. They are commonly used in coatings, adhesives, pharmaceuticals, and personal care products, and typically involve polymers, proteins, and/or surfactants. However, reports of coacervates in which one of the components is a colloid or nanoparticle are extremely rare. Such polymer-particle coacervates have the potential to harness the combined functionalities of both polymers and particles separately for use in applications such as catalysis and sensing, and could facilitate the creation of new materials that will broadly impact basic science, biosecurity, personalized health care, and the economy.

An interesting challenge of this work is that simple nanoparticles, such as silica spheres are incompatible with liquid complex coacervates. Thus, our approach was to modify well-defined silica nanoparticles by attaching negatively-charged polymers. We explored the effect of varying the length and density of polymer chains attached to the particle surface, the relative amount of positive and negative charges from polymers present in our mixture, and the salt concentration on the resulting coacervates. We were able to formulate stable liquid complex coacervates from mixtures of negatively-charged brushy particles and a positively-charged polymer. Our results showed that while traditional polymer-only coacervates form complexes with a 1:1 mixture of positive and negative polymer species, our coacervates form coacervates that possess a deficit of the brushy particle species. In fact, our negatively-charged brushy particles were relatively dilute in the resulting complex, and were spatially isolated from each other by a sea of surrounding positively-charged polymer. This effect is specifically a result of the use of brushy particles, and could be used to create novel materials based on coacervation that carry a net charge. Overall, this work demonstrated that employing a charged polymer brush as a means to integrate solid nanoparticles into coacervates has unusual and unanticipated effects. 

This project provided research opportunities for one graduate student and one postdoctoral researcher. To-date this award has resulted in one graduate dissertation and one invention disclosure. One-to-two peer reviewed manuscripts are also anticipated from this work. We presented our results at numerous conferences at the local, national, and international level. From this project, the PIs have participated in outreach through the Summer Engineering Institute for High School students (SENGI), the annual Women in Engineering & Computing Day at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, and outreach between high school students and local elementary school students. Undergraduate and graduate students also expanded their knowledge of this phenomenon through participation in a Colloidal Phenomenon class at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2022
Modified by: Sarah Perry

Image
  • Schematic depiction of brushy particle coacervates showing the significant separation between the anionic brushy particles, surrounded by a sea of positively-charged polymer
    M. Zhou, M. Santore, S.L. Perry
    Copyrighted
    Sarah Perry
    Brushy Particle Coacervates
